conclusion: To find the effective value of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in the coil.
Magnetic flux through the coil is given by Î¦ = B â‹… A â‹… cos(Î¸).
B is the magnetic induction intensity, A is the area of the coil, Î¸ is the angle between the magnetic field and the normal to the coil.
For a square coil with side length L, the area A is L^2.
The angle Î¸ as a function of time t is Î¸ = Ï‰t.
Induced EMF in the coil is given by Faraday's Law: ğ“” = -N dÎ¦/dt.
Substitute Î¦ = B â‹… L^2 â‹… cos(Ï‰t) into the EMF equation.
Differentiate Î¦ with respect to time t: dÎ¦/dt = -B â‹… L^2 â‹… Ï‰ sin(Ï‰t).
Substitute back into Faraday's Law: ğ“” = N â‹… B â‹… L^2 â‹… Ï‰ sin(Ï‰t).
The effective value (RMS value) of the induced EMF is ğ“”_rms = ğ“”_max/âˆš2.
The maximum value of the induced EMF occurs when sin(Ï‰t) = 1: ğ“”_max = N â‹… B â‹… L^2 â‹… Ï‰.
The effective value is ğ“”_rms = (N â‹… B â‹… L^2 â‹… Ï‰)/âˆš2.
The effective value of the induced electromotive force in the coil is (N â‹… B â‹… L^2 â‹… Ï‰)/âˆš2.
